dataset.title: Alaskan Peatland Experiment: Community structure and productivity data for 2007-2010 II - Species Abundance

address.deliveryPoint: Biology and Wildlife Irving I; North Koyukuk Dr.
Department of Integrative Biology University of Guelph
Alaska Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit University of Alaska Fairbanks Irving I Building
Boreal Ecology Cooperative Research Unit, PNW Research Station, USDA Forest Service, P.O. Box 756780,University of Alaska Fairbanks

abstract.para: This dataset contains abundance for vascular and non vascular plants at the Alaska Peatland Experiment in 2007 and 2009. Two peatland types are included, a bog site and a fen site. Within the fen site a water table manipulation has been ongiong since 2005, with control, lowered and raised water table treatment plots. Measurements collected in 2007 included quadrats passively warmed using open top chamebr (OTC), although these quadrats were not measured in 2009. Data at the bog was measured in 2009, and plots include an area established within the lowland black spruce permafrost plateau (permafrost), and two plots established within collapse scars embedded within the plateau. One collapse scar formed ~ 45 years ago (old collapse) and the other formed ~ 25 years ago based upon aerial photography provided by the BCEF LTER. The data provided in this data set can be sorted by year, site and plot, in addition to warming treatment.

section.title: Access to Data
section.para: While metadata will be freely available to those requesting it, the data manager will assure that any restrictions on access to data sets in the database will be enforced. Data will not be released without proper permission first being obtained from the investigator who generated the data.

section.title: Use of data
section.para: Researchers should receive adequate acknowledgment for the use of their data by others and should be provided with copies of publications using their data. Users of data from the data base must be aware that data is not to be sold or redistributed.

section.title: Citing Bonanza Creek LTER Datasets
section.para: It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists. Thus, the Data User will properly cite the Data Set in any publications or in the metadata of any derived data products that were produced using the Data Set.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: lowland open fen with daily access during the growing season

section.title: corrections
section.para: Species names were cross checked, and data entry errors were corrected by double entry.

section.title: Experimental Design
section.para: The bog site contains 3 plots, one in an area of stable permafrost (Permafrost plot), one in a thermokarst collapse scar ~45 years old and another collapse scar ~ 25 years old. At the fen site there are three water table manipulation plots ( control, lowered, and raised) with 3 open top chambers nested within each plot (data from OTCs was not collected, unless otherwise noted).

section.title: Methods
section.para: FIELD: Plant community species composition was determined using the point frame method (Hollingsworth et al., 2010, Jonasson et al., 1988) for calculating absolute abundance, during peak biomass. Point frame quadrats covered an area of 1 m2, and represented a total of 20 point readings per quadrat, with multiple hits on vegetation with canopy height at each point. Absolute abundance for each species was calculated as a ratio of the number of hits per 20 readings within a quadrat. Measurements were recorded only at the fen site in 2007, with 6 quadrats per water table treatment (3 in open top chamber and 3 without OTCs). I repeated this design at the fen site for quadrats without OTCs in 2009 (n= 3). I also measured species abundance in 2009 in the bog site with 4, 4 and 6 quadrats in the permafrost, old collapse and new collapse plots respectively. Point frame quadrats were placed randomly within each plot. LAB: Sedge species were identified following nomenclature by Tande and Lipkin (2003); all other vascular species were identified following Hult√©n (1968). Moss genera followed Seppelt et al. (2008). Species were classified into: (1) plant growth forms for living vascular plants: grass, sedge, tree, deciduous shrubs (D.Shrub), evergreen shrubs (E.Shrub), and herbaceous forbs (Forb); (2) growth forms for mosses: brown moss (Brown), feather moss (Feather) and Sphagnum sp. (Sphagnum); or (3) dead plant groups: coarse woody debris (Coarwood), fine woody debris (Finewood), leaf litter (Littleav) and standing dead (Stdead).

section.title: Sampling Frequency
section.para: Data was collected every two years. *Note abundance measurements were made again in 2011
